description: Test your knowledge of Christmas traditions, history, and celebrations

questions.question: Which country started the tradition of putting up Christmas trees?
questions.funFact: The first decorated Christmas tree was in Riga, Latvia, in 1510!
questions.story: The modern Christmas tree tradition began in 16th century Germany, where devout Christians brought decorated trees into their homes. Prince Albert, Queen Victoria's German husband, popularized the custom in England in 1848 when he set up a Christmas tree at Windsor Castle.

questions.question: What is the best-selling Christmas song of all time?
options: All I Want for Christmas Is You
questions.funFact: Bing Crosby's hit has sold over 50 million copies worldwide!
questions.story: Written by Irving Berlin and performed by Bing Crosby, 'White Christmas' was first released in 1942 during World War II. Its nostalgic lyrics resonated deeply with soldiers stationed overseas and their families back home, making it a timeless holiday classic.

questions.question: In Australia, what do they call Santa Claus?
questions.funFact: Australian Christmas celebrations often include beach barbecues and surfing!
questions.story: In Australia, Christmas occurs during summer, leading to unique traditions. While they use the name Father Christmas, he is often depicted wearing lighter clothing and sometimes arrives on a surfboard or in a ute (pickup truck) pulled by kangaroos instead of reindeer.

questions.question: Which plant is traditionally used to make a Christmas wreath?
questions.funFact: Holly leaves and berries are often used in Christmas decorations!
questions.story: Holly is a plant with glossy green leaves and bright red berries, commonly used in Christmas wreaths and decorations. Its association with Christmas dates back to ancient times when it was believed to have protective powers. Holly is also a symbol of eternal life and was used in winter solstice celebrations.

questions.question: What is the name of the traditional Christmas ballet?
questions.funFact: 'The Nutcracker' is a popular ballet performed during the Christmas season!
questions.story: 'The Nutcracker' is a ballet composed by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, based on a story by E.T.A. Hoffmann. It tells the tale of a young girl named Clara who receives a magical nutcracker doll on Christmas Eve. The ballet is known for its enchanting music and has become a holiday favorite around the world.

questions.question: Which country is credited with starting the tradition of the Christmas tree?
questions.funFact: The tradition of decorating Christmas trees originated in Germany!
questions.story: The modern Christmas tree tradition began in 16th-century Germany, where devout Christians brought decorated trees into their homes. Prince Albert, Queen Victoria's German husband, popularized the custom in England in 1848 when he set up a Christmas tree at Windsor Castle.

questions.question: What is the name of the reindeer with a red nose?
questions.funFact: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer is a beloved Christmas character!
questions.story: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer is a fictional character created in 1939 by Robert L. May for a Christmas-themed story. Rudolph is known for his glowing red nose, which helps guide Santa's sleigh through foggy weather. The story was later adapted into a popular song and television special.

questions.question: Which holiday song was originally written for Thanksgiving?
questions.funFact: 'Jingle Bells' was originally written for a Thanksgiving celebration!
questions.story: 'Jingle Bells' is a popular holiday song written by James Lord Pierpont in 1857. Originally titled 'The One Horse Open Sleigh', it was intended for a Thanksgiving program at a church in Savannah, Georgia. The song's catchy melody and festive lyrics have made it a Christmas classic.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas meal in England?
questions.funFact: Roast turkey with all the trimmings is a traditional Christmas meal in England!
questions.story: In England, Christmas dinner is a festive meal typically featuring roast turkey, stuffing, roasted vegetables, and cranberry sauce. The meal is often followed by Christmas pudding, a rich dessert made with dried fruits and spices. This tradition dates back to the Victorian era and is enjoyed by families across the country.

questions.question: Which country is known for the Christmas tradition of 'KFC for Christmas'?
questions.funFact: In Japan, it's a popular tradition to eat KFC on Christmas Day!
questions.story: In Japan, eating KFC for Christmas has become a popular tradition since the 1970s. The idea was sparked by a successful marketing campaign by KFC, which positioned their fried chicken as a festive meal for the holiday season. Today, many Japanese families order KFC in advance to enjoy on Christmas Day.

questions.question: What is the name of the character who steals Christmas in Dr. Seuss's book?
questions.funFact: The Grinch is a character created by Dr. Seuss who tries to steal Christmas!
questions.story: The Grinch is a fictional character created by Dr. Seuss in the book 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas!' The story follows the Grinch, a grouchy creature who attempts to ruin Christmas for the residents of Whoville. However, he ultimately learns the true meaning of the holiday and has a change of heart.

questions.question: Which country is known for the tradition of 'Las Posadas' during Christmas?
questions.funFact: Las Posadas is a traditional Mexican celebration leading up to Christmas!
questions.story: Las Posadas is a nine-day celebration in Mexico that commemorates the journey of Mary and Joseph to Bethlehem. Each evening, a procession reenacts their search for lodging, followed by festivities including music, food, and piñatas. The celebration culminates on Christmas Eve with a special mass and feast.

questions.question: What is the name of the traditional Italian Christmas cake?
questions.funFact: Panettone is a sweet bread loaf enjoyed during the Christmas season in Italy!
questions.story: Panettone is a traditional Italian Christmas cake that originated in Milan. It is a tall, dome-shaped sweet bread loaf filled with candied fruits and raisins. Panettone is often enjoyed with a glass of wine or a cup of coffee during the holiday season and is a popular gift item.

questions.question: Which country is known for the Christmas market tradition?
questions.funFact: Germany is famous for its traditional Christmas markets, known as 'Weihnachtsmärkte'!
questions.story: Christmas markets, or 'Weihnachtsmärkte', are a cherished tradition in Germany, dating back to the late Middle Ages. These festive markets feature stalls selling handmade crafts, holiday decorations, and seasonal treats like mulled wine and gingerbread. They are a popular destination for locals and tourists alike during the holiday season.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas flower?
questions.funFact: Poinsettias are native to Central America and are known as the 'Flor de Noche Buena'!
questions.story: The poinsettia is a popular Christmas plant known for its bright red and green foliage. It is native to Central America, particularly southern Mexico, where it is known as the 'Flor de Noche Buena', meaning 'Christmas Eve Flower'. The plant was named after Joel Poinsett, the first U.S. ambassador to Mexico, who introduced it to the United States in the 1820s.

questions.question: Which country is credited with starting the Christmas tree tradition?
questions.funFact: The Christmas tree tradition dates back to the 16th century in Germany!
questions.story: The tradition of decorating Christmas trees originated in Germany in the 16th century. Devout Christians brought decorated trees into their homes, and it is believed that Martin Luther, the Protestant reformer, was the first to add lighted candles to a tree. The custom spread throughout Europe and eventually to America, becoming a beloved holiday tradition.

questions.question: What is the name of the traditional Christmas ballet?
questions.funFact: The Nutcracker ballet is based on a story by E.T.A. Hoffmann!
questions.story: The Nutcracker is a classic Christmas ballet composed by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, based on the story 'The Nutcracker and the Mouse King' by E.T.A. Hoffmann. Premiering in 1892, the ballet tells the tale of a young girl named Clara who receives a nutcracker doll for Christmas and is transported to a magical world. The Nutcracker has become a holiday favorite, performed by ballet companies around the world.

questions.question: Which reindeer is known for having a shiny red nose?
questions.funFact: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer was created as a promotional character in 1939!
questions.story: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer is a fictional character created by Robert L. May in 1939 as part of a promotional campaign for Montgomery Ward, a department store. The story of Rudolph, who is initially shunned by the other reindeer for his glowing red nose but later becomes a hero, has become a beloved Christmas tale. The character was popularized by the song 'Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer', written by Johnny Marks and recorded by Gene Autry in 1949.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas dessert of Italy?
questions.funFact: This festive bread takes several days to prepare using traditional methods!
questions.story: Panettone originated in Milan during the Renaissance period. This tall, cylindrical sweet bread is made through a complex process of curing the dough, which takes several days. The long preparation time creates its distinctive fluffy texture. According to legend, the bread was created by a noble baker named Toni, hence the name 'Pan de Toni' (Toni's bread).

questions.question: Which country started the tradition of Christmas cards?
questions.funFact: The first commercial Christmas cards were produced in the 1840s!
questions.story: The tradition of sending Christmas cards began in 1843 when Sir Henry Cole commissioned artist John Callcott Horsley to design the first commercial Christmas card in London. Cole, who was too busy to write individual Christmas greetings, had 1,000 cards printed. This innovative solution to holiday correspondence quickly became popular throughout England and later spread worldwide.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas Eve meal in Poland?
questions.funFact: This feast traditionally begins when the first star appears in the sky!
questions.story: Wigilia is the traditional Christmas Eve supper in Poland, consisting of twelve meatless dishes representing the twelve apostles. The meal begins when the first star is spotted in the evening sky, reminiscent of the Star of Bethlehem. An extra place setting is always left empty for an unexpected guest, symbolizing hospitality and remembrance of loved ones who cannot be present.

questions.question: Which city started the tradition of the Christmas tree?
questions.funFact: A plaque marks the site of the first decorated tree from 1510!
questions.story: The first documented Christmas tree was displayed in Riga, Latvia, in 1510. The Brotherhood of Blackheads, a guild of unmarried merchants, erected and decorated a tree in their guild hall during the Christmas season. They adorned it with paper flowers and celebrated around it before burning it in a ceremony. A plaque in Riga's Town Hall Square marks this historic spot.

questions.question: What is a traditional Christmas decoration in the Philippines?
questions.funFact: These star-shaped lanterns symbolize the guiding light of Bethlehem!
questions.story: The Parol is a star-shaped Christmas lantern unique to Filipino culture. Originally made from simple materials like bamboo and paper, modern Parols can be elaborate creations featuring shells, LED lights, and intricate designs. The tradition began in the 1900s and continues to be a cherished part of Filipino Christmas celebrations, with entire communities competing to create the most beautiful designs.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas pudding of Australia?
questions.funFact: This dessert was created to honor a famous Russian ballerina's visit!
questions.story: The Pavlova, a meringue-based dessert topped with whipped cream and fresh fruit, has become a Christmas staple in Australia. Created in the 1920s to honor Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova during her tour of Australia and New Zealand, the dessert's light and airy texture was inspired by her graceful dancing. Its white color and red berry decorations make it perfect for Christmas celebrations.

questions.question: Which country celebrates Christmas with a giant goat?
questions.funFact: This massive straw structure has become famous worldwide!
questions.story: The Gävle Goat is a giant version of the traditional Swedish Yule Goat, erected annually in Gävle, Sweden. Standing over 40 feet tall, the goat is built of straw on a wooden frame. First erected in 1966, it has become famous not only for its size but also for the local tradition of trying to protect it from pranksters who attempt to burn it down, adding an element of drama to the holiday season.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas bread of Germany?
questions.funFact: Medieval bakers needed special permission to use butter in this festive bread!
questions.story: Stollen is a fruit bread made with dried fruits, nuts, and spices, traditionally enjoyed during the Christmas season. The bread's shape is said to represent the baby Jesus wrapped in swaddling clothes. Originally a simple Advent fasting food, Stollen evolved when bakers received permission from the Pope to use butter instead of oil, making it the rich, festive bread we know today.

questions.question: Which animal helps deliver presents in Spain?
questions.funFact: This unique tradition involves a hollow log decorated with a smiling face!
questions.story: Caga Tió, or the 'pooping log,' is a unique Catalan Christmas tradition. Families 'feed' the decorated log throughout December and cover it with a blanket to keep it warm. On Christmas Eve, children sing special songs and hit the log with sticks, and it 'delivers' small gifts and treats. This quirky tradition combines elements of magic and humor in holiday gift-giving.

questions.question: What is the traditional Christmas market called in German?
questions.funFact: These enchanting markets date back to the Middle Ages!
questions.story: Christkindlmarkt, meaning 'Christ Child Market,' is a street market associated with the celebration of Christmas during the four weeks of Advent. The tradition began in German-speaking parts of Europe in the Middle Ages. These markets feature wooden stalls selling seasonal items, traditional crafts, and holiday treats like mulled wine and gingerbread, creating a magical atmosphere that draws visitors from around the world.
